720632f-a.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East)
720632f-a.text:
Irvinog Flace (foreground), east side, north from E. 17th
Street (right, not seen) to Gramercy Park, showing an out-
door parking lot at the former Nersey Chocolate Go. plant site.
Across same apnear buildinos on the north side of E. 18th Street,
east from lIrving Place.
Pebruary 4, 1938
P.L. Sperr

720634f-a.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street
720634f-a.text:
Irving Place, at and adjoining S.W. corner of 17th Street, showing
49 Irving Place, the corner house which is supposed to have
been at one time the home of Washington Irving, and is accordingly
known as the Nashington Irving house. The little railing around
the roof of the house is not seen in photographs as early as
1909. Adjoining 47 Irving Place may be seen part of the north
wall of the Westminster Hotel, which will be demolished in 1909.
About 1900.
0ift of W. M. Van Der Weyde.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
1N~ NW  2NE4  Ny. 77 822
(2)
The same, a generation later. The Borgfeldt Building, shown in
part at the left, was erected in 1909 on the site of the West-
minster Hotel.
August 30, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

720639f-a.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East)
720639f-a.text:
54 and 56 (right to left) Irving Place,adjoining and north
of the N. E. corner of E. 17th Stret, showing two 3 story former
private dwellings. That, with the bay window is now occupied by
the Cooperative Cafeteria, an enterprise long associated with the
wife of Norman Thomas, the Socialist.
June 1938
  George D. Chinn
NO REPRODUTIONS1

720636f-a.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East)
720636f-a.text:
49 Irving Place, at the S.W. corner of E. 17th Street, showing
a commemorative tablet on the 17th Street side of same. This shows
a bas-relief of a profile of Washington IIrving, who was supposed to have
lived and worked here.
July 1937.
ift of Geo. D. Chinn.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

720638f-a.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East)
720638f-a.text:
49-47 Irving Place, (left) at and adjoining the S.W. corner of East
17th Street. The corner structure, No. 49, with its entrance on 17th
Street, is supposed to have been the residence of Washington Irving and
is popularly known as the Washington Irving House. Shown on the right
and north of same is a 3-story building, No. 120 East 17th Street.
July 1937.
GeBrge D. Chinn.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

720643f-b.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street
720643f-b.text:
(1)
Irving Place, east side, from 54 Irving Place, just north of 17th
Street, to the S.E. corner of 19th Street. The former Huyler Con-
fectionery Works are shown at and adjoining the S.W. corner of 18th
Street. The builcing first occupied by this company in this location
was the corner house (1885 or a little earlier).
The sign on 54 Irving Place, at the extreme right, is that of a
Consumers' Co-operative Cafeteria.
July 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
982-86 Irving Place,East side and Northwards from East 19th St. to
Grammeroy Park.
August 22nd,1940.
P.L.Sperr,
No Neproductions.

720635f.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East).
720635f.text:
Irving Place, at, adjoinin; and south of the S.W. corner of East 17th
Street. Also shown is East 17th Street, south side, west from Irving
P1ace, to, but not including Union Square, East. Corner building shown,
No. 49 Irving Place, is the Washington Irving House, and now is the home of
the Author's League Club.
About 1912.
Underwood \& Undcrwood.
NO REPPODUCTIONS.

720628f-a.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East)
720628f-a.text:
Irving Place, north from but not including East 17th Street, showing
road bed being repaired by the W.P.A. Intersection appearing in the fore-
ground is East 18th Street.
September 2, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

720637f-a.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East)
720637f-a.text:
47-49 Irving Place, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of East 17th
Street. The corner building; No. 49 with its entrance on 17th Street, was
supposed to have been the residence of Washington Irving and is popularly
known as the Washington Irving HIouse. The Washington Irving Hlgh School
for Girls, across Irving Place (east side between 16th and 17th Streets),
erected a commemorative bust of Washington Irving in 1936, which faces this
landmark.
1936.
V.P.A. Photo.
Pederal Writers Project.
CREDIT LINE IDPERATIVE ON ALL EPRODUCTIONS.

720640f.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East)
720640f.text:
B5 Irving Place, west side, between East 17th and East 18th Streets,
showing the O. Henry House, in which the great American short story writer
lived and worked.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

720633f-a.text:
Trving Place at East 17th Street, south east corner
showlng he Washington Arving High School for Girls.

720644f-a.text:
Trving Place, west side, south from East 18th to 17th Streets, as

55 Irving Place, west side, between East 17th and 18th Streets, show-

720642f-a.title: Manhattan: Irving Place - 17th Street (East)
720642f-a.text:
Irving Place, east side, north from No. 58 a point midway between
East 17th and 18th Streets, and across the latter,showing pavement con-
ditions in front of the now demolished (1937) Huylers Confectionery
Plant, Nos. 60-64, at the S.E. corner of East 18th Street.
August 7, 1936.
